awd_titl_txt: Optimizing Wear and Corrosion Resistance of Superlattice Coatings through Atomic-Scale Design
awd_abstract_narration:
The design of new engineering materials resistant to both wear damage and corrosion degradation is in increasing demand for components in complex service conditions, such as biomedical implants, hydraulic systems, nuclear power plants, marine applications and offshore industries. Unfortunately, many engineering approaches to increasing strength in alloys can result in reduced corrosion performance. This award supports fundamental research to develop a comprehensive understanding of effective design principles that can mitigate wear and corrosion in metallic coatings. The research will focus on superlattice coatings, which are layered metallic systems with individual layer thickness below 10 nanometers, and offer great potential to provide both wear and corrosion resistance. The knowledge developed from this research will lead to design strategies for new metals and coatings with an optimal combination of high strength and excellent wear and corrosion resistance. The use of such materials may lead to significant economical savings in various industries. This program will additionally provide students with a unique educational and research experience. Outreach programs are included, which will help stimulate interests in STEM fields among young students and broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research activities. 

Superlattice coatings offer great opportunity to improve wear and corrosion resistance simultaneously. Little is known, however, about how key materials properties such as modulation wavelength, interface structure, and residual stress affect deformation and degradation mechanisms. This research is centered on a comprehensive study that integrates materials processing, characterization, wear and corrosion testing, and computer simulations. A finite element electrochemical model will be combined with experiments to design the optimum superlattice architecture. Advanced materials characterization will be coupled with atomistic and finite element modeling to understand the roles of key microstructural parameters on wear and corrosion resistance. With greater understanding of the deformation and degradation mechanisms, this bottom-up design approach may pave the way for creating wear and corrosion resistant structural materials needed in complex service conditions.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Wear and corrosion are estimated to cost more than $300 billion per year in the US. The design of new engineering materials resistant to both wear damage and corrosion degradation is hence highly demanded in complex service conditions, such as biomedical implants, hydraulic systems, nuclear power plants, marine and offshore industries etc. Unfortunately, there is typically a tradeoff between wear and corrosion resistance, even for important passive metals such as Al, Ti alloys and stainless steel. To solve this challenge, this research combined experiments, atomic-scale characterization, modelling, and data science to study the wear and corrosion (i.e. tribocorrosion) behavior of aluminum-based superlattices, i.e. metallic multilayer coatings with less than ~ 10 nm individual layer thickness. It was found that these multilayered materials exhibited ultrahigh tribocorrosion resistance owing to the presence of abundant interfaces and nanoscale chemical modulation. The interfaces strengthened the material and increased wear resistance by effectively restricting plastic deformation. The nanoscale chemical modulation reduced micro-galvanic corrosion and surface reactivity. Specifically, among several Al/X (X = Ti, Mg and Cu) multilayered systems studied, Al/Ti superlattice coatings with ~ 3 nm individual layer thickness was found to exhibit ultrahigh corrosion resistance. The nano layering strategy was believed to increase the surface work function of Al and Cl adatoms adsorption energy, thus reducing the surface reactivity and pitting susceptibility. In addition to the experimental efforts, a multiphysics finite element-based model was developed and validated for predicting tribocorrosion behavior of superlattices by accounting for wear, corrosion, and their synergy. This model showed accelerated material loss in the anode layers near the top interfaces and close to the wear track edges, due to the galvanic coupling of the individual layers and strain-accelerated corrosion. Finally, a physics-informed data-driven surrogate model was used to model the finite element simulations and successfully captured both input and output uncertainties. The developed data science method realized the smallest predictive error as well as generating the most reasonable confidence intervals with the best coverage on testing tribocorrosion data points.

For broader impacts, this research has 1) identified how multilayered architecture enhanced wear and corrosion resistance compared to monolithic coatings; 2) determined the optimum individual layer thickness and constituents that lowered the wear rate and corrosion kinetics; and 3) quantified the tribocorrosion resistance and characterized the tribocorroded surfaces of Al-based superlattices. The obtained results will lead to better design guidelines for metal coatings to be used in harsh environments and service conditions. In addition, a comprehensive education and outreach program was developed at the University of South Florida and Virginia Tech to improve the participation of females and underrepresented minority students in STEM fields.  Hands-on demonstrations and lab demos related to materials research have been performed to local K-12 students and teachers. Research opportunities have been provided to both undergraduate and graduate students at the two institutions. Educational videos have been published on YouTube to engage and educate an even broader audience in STEM. This project also provided hands-on lab experience for two REUs at Virginia Tech. In addition, the data science efforts from this project published data and codes that are shared to the entire research community.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/21/2021
Modified by: Wenjun Cai
